captions.text:
JAMIE ROBINSON: We're fresh
out of the city center.

This is Sean Matic, local
actor and motorcycle
enthusiast.

And we're on a couple of
low-powered dual sport

machines, here in the San
Bernardino mountains to get
dirty, sweaty, and nasty.
Welcome to "RideApart."
[HEAVY ROCK MUSIC PLAYING]
[MOTORCYCLE ENGINES]
[MOTORCYCLE ENGINES]
[MOTORCYCLE ENGINES]
[MOTORCYCLE ENGINES]

JAMIE ROBINSON: Oh, this
is the life, isn't it?
SEAN MATIC: Oh, it's gorgeous.

I'd like to jump in
there right now.
Man, it's hot.
[SIGHS]

JAMIE ROBINSON: I've been amazed
at this little bike.
It goes everywhere.
SEAN MATIC: They do.

It's my first time ever riding
the bike to the off-road spot.
[LAUGHS]
JAMIE ROBINSON: Oh yeah?
SEAN MATIC: Yeah.

Always had the trailer
[INAUDIBLE].
It's pretty cool.

JAMIE ROBINSON: Yeah,
get the trailer.

Boy, we just left today,
left the city, and
then we're out here.
What else do you need?

Talk full of gas, some
water, perfect.

Because off-road riding, you're
generally at quite a

slow pace, but the ground is
always moving and changing and
nothing's very consistent.

So your mind's having to think
and deal with many things all
of the time, you know?

And that really then helps you
when you're on the road,

because the road, most of the
time, is very consistent, and

then you can just think about
where to position
yourself and braking.

Off-road riding is just
a fantastic way
of developing skills.
We're out here to--

I just wanted to really find
out what these dual sports
were going to be like.
They're pretty small.

This comes in at just
over $4,000.
It's an amazing motorcycle.

I want to see what it can do
off-road, and pretty much, you
can handle everything.
SEAN MATIC: Yeah.
Let's do more exploring, then.
Yeah.
[HEAVY ROCK MUSIC PLAYING]
SEAN MATIC: [INAUDIBLE].
[MOTORCYCLE ENGINES ROAR]
[MOTORCYCLE ENGINE]

JAMIE ROBINSON: I've ridden
half the way up
here on this bike.
Fancy swapping?
SEAN MATIC: Yeah.

I was looking, that thing looks
about 75 pounds lighter.
JAMIE ROBINSON: Yeah.
[LAUGHS]

I'm game for a bit
of extra power.

You look like you've been having
a lot of fun with the
torque and the power buttons.

SEAN MATIC: Yeah, it's good for
out-of-shape old farts.

I haven't ridden
in a long time.

Just, like, lug it and don't
shift, it's great.

JAMIE ROBINSON: You'll have a
lot of fun on this, I swear.
I mean, it is really light.

It makes it really easy
to ride the bumps.
[HEAVY ROCK MUSIC PLAYING]
[MOTORCYCLE ENGINES]
[MOTORCYCLE ENGINES]
[MOTORCYCLE ENGINES]

JAMIE ROBINSON: Yeah, we had the
conversation earlier that

you were quite surprised
at how well these
bikes ride on the roads.

SEAN MATIC: Yeah, I mean, I
didn't expect to go into those

corners so hard, and I saw you
going and your front tire
wasn't giving out.

So I'm like, I guess
they grip.
And they're really light.
The bikes are really light.

The last time I rode a dual
sport, that thing was a big,
heavy thing.

It didn't really feel
like a dirt bike.

You kind of could maybe do it,
but these things feel almost
like proper dirt bikes.
Especially the Honda, really.
JAMIE ROBINSON: Yeah, yeah.
Very light, isn't it?
SEAN MATIC: Yeah.

JAMIE ROBINSON: And they've
all got great brakes, good
engines, light, maneuverable.

I mean, we've come out of the
city, we've taken the freeway

for quite a while, and
I didn't have any
stress on the freeway.

I mean, they're not the fastest
thing there, but I

never felt like I was in danger
or not much ever came

past us, so they're pretty
capable even though the CR was

pretty much running flat out,
the top of its RPM there.

But the minute you jump off the
freeway, I mean, it's the
bike to be on, aren't they?
They're so much fun.

SEAN MATIC: Yeah, yeah,
they're a hoot.

And it's not just
fun in the dirt.

They're fun on the pavement,
they're fun on these twisty
roads we were doing.
I mean, you can really hustle.

When it starts getting really
tight, you'd probably go

faster on one of these than a
regular street bike because
they're so light.

JAMIE ROBINSON: Has it surprised
you, a little 250

like this Honda behind me
and the 400 Suzuki?

Are you surprised how powerful
they've been and what we've

been able to get out
of them today?
SEAN MATIC: Yeah, yeah.

You know, in the Honda, you've
got to carry a little more
momentum than the Suzuki.

Like you said, it doesn't
quite have the torque.

But you can get both of those
things moving, on the payment
and on the dirt.
JAMIE ROBINSON: Yeah, yeah.

And we really did push those
bikes today and push

ourselves, and got hot,
got sweaty, got dirty.

SEAN MATIC: You pushed
my [BLEEPED], oh man.

I had one moment of doubt-- you
saw the water pouring out,

I thought the water bottles
opened up in my backpack on my
chatterbox.
I'm like, no, that's my sweat.
JAMIE ROBINSON: Oh man.

SEAN MATIC: I couldn't
believe it.

JAMIE ROBINSON: You were
sweaty, though.

SEAN MATIC: I was really
tired, but I had
a blast, you know.
JAMIE ROBINSON: Yeah.

SEAN MATIC: That's
like the funnest
way to torture yourself.
[BOTH LAUGH]

JAMIE ROBINSON: So really, we're
looking at motorcycles

here that people can really
develop their
skills on, can't they?

They might be only a 250, they
might only be a 400, but you

can take a novice rider on one
of these bikes, and they can
go a long way.
SEAN MATIC: Yeah, big time.

And bang for your buck,
especially if you live
somewhere like this.

It's like, you can do
everything on it.

JAMIE ROBINSON: The CRM is
a pretty decent-looking
motorcycle, isn't it?

It really does look like its
motocross big brother.
SEAN MATIC: It does.

JAMIE ROBINSON: Upside-down
front forks, solid breaks.

It's a lot of bike
for its money.
SEAN MATIC: Yeah.
Yeah, and I like the color.

You've got a little flash of the
gold forks, and a little

white, a little black,
a little red.

Honda did good with
that thing.
JAMIE ROBINSON: Yeah.
I think it's brilliant.

I think it's a really, really
great motorcycle.

And just on the dash, having
everything in the digital

display was just
what we wanted.
Fuel--

all the information right
there in front of you.

SEAN MATIC: Yeah, and that
shocked me when I hopped on

after we swapped bikes,
and I'm like,
digital dash fuel gauge?

I'm like, dirt bikes have
come a long way, baby!
Virginia Slims!
[LAUGHS]
JAMIE ROBINSON: Yeah, yeah.
They really have.

And going to the Suzuki, I mean,
the Suzuki is a really
solid bike.
Great engine, isn't it?

I mean, a really, really, really
strong motorcycle.
Good suspension.

I had no problems riding that
off-road or on-road, even.
Really solid bike.

SEAN MATIC: Yeah, it's
a good bike.

It's like a total
workhorse bike.

JAMIE ROBINSON: Are you pretty
surprised in that a little

250, a little 400 dual sport
bikes are can cover the ground
and the range that we have?

We've done city, freeway, a
whole load of dual sports,
some technical stuff.

And we're here at the end of
day and the bikes are not
missing a beat.
SEAN MATIC: No, they haven't.
They've been great.
They're solid performers.

They really live up to the name
dual sport because kind

of like you said, we covered
it all and the bikes never
skipped a beat once.

JAMIE ROBINSON: Yeah,
brilliant, eh?
Absolutely fantastic.

I really think that people
should be looking at these

bikes to develop their
skills on.

They're light, you can get a lot
out of them, you take them

off-road where you really do
develop your skills off-road.

These bikes are just made
for it, aren't they?
SEAN MATIC: Yeah, I agree.
I mean, I learned on dirt.

I always say the best place
to learn is on dirt.

But this way, you don't need
to have your pick-up
truck, or your car.

Maybe you're a teenager, you
just got your license, you're
on a tight budget.
Just ride to the trails.

JAMIE ROBINSON: Right,
that's it.
Just like we have today.
SEAN MATIC: Yeah.

JAMIE ROBINSON: Spend a bit of
time on the roads, but we've

ridden to the trails
and had a blast.

The only one point is there's
a 250 and there's a 400.

It's about 120 miles home, so
which bike are you thinking?
SEAN MATIC: [LAUGHS]
It's up to me?
I'll take the 400.
[LAUGHS]

JAMIE ROBINSON: Well, you are
the guest, so I guess I'll
give you the bigger bike.

So you have the 400,
I'll take the 250.
SEAN MATIC: All right, Jaime.

You're a gentleman
and a scholar.
Thanks for bringing me today.
[HEAVY METAL MUSIC PLAYING]
JAMIE ROBINSON: [DISGUSTED]
Is that sweat?
Oh my goodness, look at you.

SEAN MATIC: I know, you're
talking about getting dirty,

nasty, and sweaty, you're not
sweating a drop, here, man.
Look at me.
JAMIE ROBINSON: Go on, local--
aspiring--
aspiring actor, local--

actor and motorcycle enthusiast,
and we're on a
couple of low-powered sports--
actor and mot--
[SIGHS]
[ENGINE PETERS OUT]

title: Dual-Sports: Honda CRF250L vs Suzuki DR-Z400 -- /RideApart

comments.text:

comments.author: Neil Wilkes

comments.text:
I have a TTR 230 and it is fantastic. although it is not street legal so it 
does not have much use for me. I am looking at the CRF250L, XT250, DRZ 400 
and WR 250 for my seccond bike. I rode a YZ 450 before and I think it is 
just to much for me, would I have the same probem with the DRZ 400? Or 
should I go with a 250cc bike? I am 5,8 and I weight about 150 pounds. ﻿
comments.author: CYRRYANC97

comments.text:
+CYRRYANC97 
There are worlds between
the yz450 and the drz400. You shouldn't have any problems with the
drz, it's light for a dual Sport, nearly unbreakable, has a great
engine, it's not too powerful but it's very old school and is too
heavy for some "real" Enduro riding. If you want a more
serious enduro bike with the right amount of power for a beginner,
you should take a look at the KTM Freeride 350 and 250, Highly
recommended. But if you just wanna ride some trails and enjoy light
riding in the local Forest you should take the drz instead.

comments.text: Good stuff !!﻿

comments.author: DaytonaMisfits

comments.text: the war ended, go somewhere nice
comments.author: The Man With No Name

comments.text:
Did the 2 of you get paid off by Honda? The honda weighs in 3 pounds 
heavier than the Suzuki. DRZ has more travel with better forks, just 
because the Honda forks are inverted doesn't mean they work better or are 
better. They don't have the adjustments the Suzuki has. I was going to buy 
the CRF250l but found such a good deal on the DRZ I had to get it. The 
Honda is shorter that's why it may feel lighter to you. As for power you 
cannot compare a 250 with a 400. The Suzuki has proven it's self for years 
now and I'm a big Honda fan. Have had CR's & XR's for years along with DR 
350's. New the Honda is much cheaper than the Suzuki. The after market 
parts that everyone buys & puts on the bikes cost the same for both bikes. 
The MPG on the Honda wins of course with it's smaller motor & fuel 
injection. But I get about 65 MPG on my Suzuki. So this would be an easy 
choice if your a beginner than the Honda would be the best bike but if 
you've been riding for awhile then the Suzuki would still be the winner 
after 15 years of production.
 If money is not a problem for you look at KTM or Husqvarna for the best 
dual sport bike.﻿
comments.author: Mr Meoff

comments.text: DRZ is a workhorse. Carburetors are for the birds.
comments.author: Evan Ferguson

comments.text:
+CommieCat
Yeah but it's got those stupid street wheels.
comments.author: MrJumbolegz

comments.text: The 400SM also has inverted forks if that's what you're really after.

comments.author: jtm11995

comments.text:
And it's $1,600 more, if we're talking new. I'd definitely go for a used 
one, tons out there. Still like the Honda a lot, especially for the EFI and 
being a new design. Interesting that they say the Honda still feels so much 
lighter. And if you're doing daily riding the MPG on the Honda is superior. 
Depends on what you need I guess.
comments.author: turbo311

comments.text:
Its really too bad Honda did not go with a 400 cc engine. I really like the 
crf but it has 10 less hp than the drz and weighs the same as the drz at 
320 lbs. each. that's a deal breaker for me.﻿
comments.author: jeff ferguson

comments.text:
I'm with you.  I think it's time they retire the big ol 650 thumper and 
drop it to a fuel injected 500cc dual sport.  If they could get the price 
point down to the $6,000-$7,500 range I think they would sell the heck out 
of them.
comments.author: WheeliePete

comments.text:
If you go with a DRZ you should DEFINITELY go with a full exhaust upgrade, 
uncorking that multi-valve engine unleashes a monster. Also it is light 
enough to get out of a jam by yourself, or if the bike falls on top of you.﻿

comments.text: Those are some crazy leans for riding with knobbies...﻿
comments.author: SIXFLAGSDRPEPPER

comments.text:
love the video...the shots...the bikes look great..both of these bikes are 
what I am looking for to get ....but the summery at the end of the video 
didnt tell me much.. I would have like to see a little bit more comparison 
on how the bikes did in each section and who prefured what in those 
situations. I am leaning toward a 250L because of price and off-road 
performance and all the new display and electric FI .only have ever owned a 
2-stroke rt-180. So both of those bikes are big changes..I dont play on 
riding to much free-way but pleanty of HIGHWAY. Id really like to know what 
bike is better in the soft dirt-sand/ rocky arizona desert style 
environment. Seems only true thumpers makes it those conditions.﻿

comments.text: Huge Fan of the little DR200
comments.author: Zone Television

comments.text:
Stage one performance kit (FMF header and Muffler, 13T Sprocket, EJK Fuel 
Injection Unit), Airbox Mods, Taillight Kit... The bike is now about 25# 
lighter and rides like a dream. I also changed the rear sprocket from 40T 
to 42T. It has much more torque now and the throttle response greatly 
increased. Worth every cent!!!
comments.author: Tauchmeier

comments.text: I spent about 1000 $ to do the following mods:
comments.author: Tauchmeier

yes then no. you could expect to pay 2 grand more. but if you can find a

comments.text:
The only thing keeping me from not deciding is the fuel injection. I want 
the drz but I also want a fuel injection.
comments.author: sneakysnakepie1

comments.text:
Honda is very restricted out of the box but goto best dual sport bikes 
website and u can shave 20-30 lbs and increase horsepower from 18-24 with 
aroun $1000. Since the base price is so cheap its worth it for the add ons 
that give you a truely light weight bike with enough power to satisfy all 
but the hardcore off roaders.
comments.author: Robert Hierholzer

comments.text:
Well that's for you to decide. But ask yourself, what type of riding do 
you plan on doing? Are more of a dirt rider or street rider? I've never 
ridden a Super moto bike before, but i doubt it's good for long distance 
riding. Dual Sport = street, city + light dirt riding. Super Moto = street, 
city, suburban riding, stunt riding.
comments.author: You Toober

comments.text: Curb weights DRZ400s 317 lbs CRF250l 320 lbs KLX250s 297.7 WR250r 299
comments.author: C3HENRYS

comments.text:
Great ride! The CRF250l looks great and is the new kid on the block. I test 
rode one and for a 200lbs rider like myself I would take the DRZ400s better 
for its way better suspension and power. I had a 2005 and it was a great 
bike and never let me down. Changes I would make would be add a 6th gear, 
update the plastics including the headlight, and loose weight on the top 
end. I now own a 2009 KLX250s with a pipe, the air box mod, and jetted. The 
thing is just awesome!
comments.author: C3HENRYS

comments.text: Anyone here willing to gift me one?
comments.author: Darkbloodhatred

comments.text:
bothers me when ppl re use footage in their videos. makes me think you are 
liars
comments.author: Matthew Barton

comments.text:
lame review. I couldnt hear the engine, and they never said anything 
negative about the bikes or which one was better in different areas. Im 
thinking of getting the 250 because it has fuel injection
comments.author: Premium fuel only

comments.text: He said the Honda looks about 75lbs lighter, but really it's 3lbs heavier.

comments.text: SO they got hot...well don't wear black and zipped up to your neck?

ya I was born and raised there had to move here cuz money trouble so in in 
vegas but I love cali for that reason nice 95% of the time
comments.author: ReptiRider

comments.text: Haha at the end he almost said ill let you ride the better bike, the drz400
comments.author: summertop511

comments.text:
I have had my 2012 DRZ 400 S for a year now. I average 63 MPG on it. The 
bike is my daily commuter. I only made some minimal changes to mine. The 
list is as follows. 1. Put a set of Kenda 270 tires on it. 2nd some MSR 
hand guards 3rd a IMMX rack 4th a set of Unabikers Radiator Guards 5th a 
Fan override switch for REAL HOT days or trail riding. The bike has done 
close to 4,000 miles over the year. I bought it new and broke it in with 
dino oil. Then went to Mobile 1 racing 4T synthetic at 1,100.
comments.author: weld3871

comments.text: .im with ya
comments.author: gmg921

comments.text:
I have the 400SM, I have ridden a 400S and a CRF250L. These guys are either 
high or being paid to say its a close call. Because it isn't. The CRF is 
fantastic for the price (4500 bucks) but it doesn't measure up to the DRZ 
in anything other than MPG or price. The DRZ is superior in every way.
comments.author: LoudandDave

comments.text:
I don't think they have to, but people who ride dirt bikes expect a 
motorcycle with a first gear that has enough torque to carry them up steep 
dirt hills. I don't think a 100% street tuned engine could do that.
comments.author: MotoShaman

comments.text:
The engine is adjusted for more low end grunt and less top end speed, but 
the engine is based off of the CBR 250 engine. Don't really know what if 
any parts are different between the two engines.
comments.author: MotoShaman

comments.text:
I ride year round here in California. I started street riding on a FZ6 but 
after riding for a while I wish I had a DRZ 400, WR250, CRF 250L, or maybe 
even the CCW Hooligun. I find myself rarely going fast enough to utilized 
the inline 4 cylinder engine in my FZ6 and the ability to ride off road is 
much more appealing than raw speed.
comments.author: MotoShaman

comments.text:
Seems a little unfair to put the CRF250L against something significantly 
more powerful. For that price range, the KLX250 is definitely the more 
logical battle. Then again, there's not really anything else in the DRZ's 
displacement and price point either.
comments.author: dustysquito .

comments.text: What is better? A dual sport bike or a super moto?

Bro, I thought the same thing because I was in the middle of nowhere and I

finally got service on my phone and got my dad to come with his truck to 
haul it and take me home. NOW when I ride far distances and in the middle 
of nowhere I ride with friends.
